Award.AwardTitle: Harnessing the power of polymer phase interactions in the design of supramolecular interpenetrating networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Biological materials often feature complex assemblies that utilize the interaction between phases possessing disparate mechanical properties to achieve synergistic and highly tunable effects. Incorporation of this nature-inspired structural interplay into synthetic polymeric systems is proposed toward the development of mechanically-robust and functional materials. Their structures and properties will be studied and correlated in this project using a combination of advanced instrumentation. The ability to control and tune the molecular and materials architecture in complex systems addresses key scientific challenges related to mechanically adaptive behavior and controlled transport in new materials development. Such systems have potential use in a range of applications, including biomedical delivery vehicles, sensors, actuators, and membranes, and may potentially also offer advantages in terms of processability.

Graduate and undergraduate students will gain exposure to cross-cutting research -- from synthesis to processing -- and utilize these advances in the areas of mentorship and community outreach. A mentoring platform for female students and post-docs, particularly from underrepresented groups, to engage in dialogue regarding shared experiences and career pathways will be supported. An expanded partnership with a K-12 all-female independent school will provide hands-on demonstrations, career development, and safety/ethics training during a two-week science/engineering exposure program for high-school girls.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Supramolecular associations have been widely explored in elastomers, blends, and copolymer systems, and have motivated interest in the utilization of dynamic associations in the design of interpenetrating polymer networks (IPNs). IPNs provide a robust platform to explore the role of supramolecular motifs as a toughening mechanism due to the intimate interaction of the polymer phases. This research program will elucidate structural parameters and guiding principles to direct fabrication of supramolecular IPNs with tunable interfacial interactions, tailored structural heterogeneity, and synergistic mechanical behavior. Three classes of supramolecular IPNs will be explored that utilize: (1) complementary and orthogonal supramolecular associations with focus on how motifs of varying interaction strength/organization influence microstructure development and dynamics, (2) self-complementary and complementary hydrogen bonding associations with an emphasis on the correlation between the resulting IPN morphology, mechanics, and supramolecular response, and (3) particulate-reinforcement as an approach to control phase coarsening, mechanical behavior, and functionality. A full suite of structural, thermal, mechanical, and morphological characterization techniques will be utilized, including variable temperature nuclear magnetic resonance, fluorescence spectroscopy, tensile testing, dynamic mechanical analysis, atomic force microscopy, rheology, scanning electron microscopy, and X-ray and neutron scattering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature provides a myriad of examples of complex assemblies that incorporate features with different mechanical properties and dynamic associations to achieve tunability and responsiveness. Inspired by these biological materials, this project focuses on the incorporation of these structural features into a polymeric platform to address key scientific challenges related to adaptive behavior and controlled transform.  Critical to this approach is a fundamental investigation of the structure-processing-function paradigm that underpins these mechanisms. These nature-inspired systems have impact in a range of applications, including biomedical delivery vehicles, sensors, actuators, and membranes.  

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project led to the development of supramolecular polymeric materials platform for responsive material design. We investigated the role of different supramolecular functionalization strategies and supramolecular associative strengths coupled with the interplay of various polymer cores and architectures on mechanics and morphology.  Utilizing these structure-function map, we designed a chemoresponsive, supramolecular semi-interpenetrating network platform utilizing metal-ligand coordination chemistries with gradient mechanics.  We also explored magneto- and photo-responsive features in supramolecular network systems. Via strategic design, supramolecular nanocomposites were also developed that exhibited efficient self-healing and displayed directed nucleation and growth mechanisms to dictate mechanics. By controlling the method of nanofiller incorporation, supramolecular systems were also obtained with variable shape memory behavior. Additive manufacturing strategies were also employed to fabricate water- responsive supramolecular materials. A suite of characterization techniques was utilied to link molecular design, observed function, and processing parameters, including X-ray scattering, dynamic mechanical analysis, atomic force microscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Dissemination of these findings included peer-reviewed publications, oral and poster presentations at national and international conferences, and local community events.

 

Broader Impact: Graduate and undergraduate students gained exposure to cross-cutting research tools – from synthesis to processing - and were provided significant professional development and mentoring opportunities via community outreach programming.  Bio-inspiration and responsive materials provided the framework for a range of K-12 activities, including hands-on demonstrations, community discovery days, and college exposure events. A mentoring platform for female students and post-docs, particularly from underrepresented groups, to engage in dialogue regarding shared experiences and career pathways was also developed. Translation of fundamental aspects in this research have broad reaching applications, from sensor technology and biomedicine to coatings and dielectric elastomers.

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2020
Modified by: Lashanda T Korley
